entries.meaning: An accompanying sound or strain; an accompaniment.
examples: To the soft Wren or Lark’s descending trill
Murmurs sweet undersong mid jasmin bowers.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Subordinate and underlying idea, meaning or atmosphere; undertone.
examples: The mad smouldering lust which gives a sort of under-song of surging passion to the sophisticated sensuality of “Salome” [...]

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The burden of a song; the chorus; the refrain.
examples: It is not hard to observe that David’s Allelujahs are more then his Hosannas; his thanks more then his suits. Oft-times doth he praise God when be begs nothing: seldome ever doth he beg that favour for which he doth not raise up his Soul to an anticipation of Thanks: neither is this any other then the universal under-song of all his Heavenly Ditties [...]
